comment_text:
Hi Destin, I love your channel. But I'm curious is anyone can tell me an easy way to watch all of your episodes in order.
Youtube tends to jump to a newer video of yours next and then on to someone completely different. It's really annoying because I have navigate back to your list of videos and scroll through them to where I left off.
#3 back when people could fly and used normal cameras

Wow! Thanks!  My wife is a Fine Art Photographer, I'm going to try her big lens out tomorrow.
Do they have adapters like the one linked in the description for Nikons as well?

This only works on Canon because the lens opens up to maximum aperture when released.  Other brands close down to the smallest aperture when you take the lens off, so it's really hard, if not impossible, to do this trick.
Im having a hard time getting this right on my T3i, even with 3600 ISO i still get black pictures, any other tips?
Great!

you have a point with the cool photos, but, the dust issue is also not quite true, yes dust can be a pain if it is on the inner lens for the lamen terms but if using the correct cleaning gear, it wont be an issue

So lets say it does cause scratches, they are so small that you would need impressive gear to see these once the photo is taken, if they are even there at all.

Taking the lens off on most fancy cameras (looked like a Cannon 400D) is quite simple, and need to be done to change the lens
I learned about this trick from a friend, sadly my SLR refuses to take pictures without a lens cap fully in place. Though that may have to do with it being Film instead of digital.
Hi i tried with my canon 60d 18-135, it didn' work....become blur, can you tell me why ?

This works unless you have a lens that automatically closes the aperture blades when you take the lens off... But there are ways around these minor problems

@drasco61084 A DIY lens tutorial would imply its used on an SLR, so the title does say you need "one of those kind of cameras".
Thumbs up if u did same thing after watching this video

@CrunchyBrush Not all DSLR's are high end, and some of the macro lenses cost more than the lower-end DSLR's. For example my camera body cost about $420 but if I wanted a macro lens it would be $500 XDD
cooool
To be fair, if you can afford to purchase a high end camera, it is likely that you are also able to afford a macro lens, but this is pretty damn awesome.
oh.. but the title doesn't say you need one of those kind of cameras. lol not "on the cheap" unless you already have one of those.
thats only on cheap planes

@Justin5645 3 seconds is a bit arbitrary, that's more than enough time to get dust in there, just exercise common sense - if you don't do anything dumb like try this at a building site or anything that dusty, you'll be fine. If you really care about your camera, you'll have a lens brush and huffer anyway and a speck or two of dust will be easily removed without scratching the glass...saying 'don't do this' is a knee-jerk reaction which is unhelpful in the extreme.

PLEASE DO NOT DO THIS! If you take the lens off only keep it off for under 3 seconds. Even a single speck of dust could ruin your camera forever (because of microscopic scratches).

@destinws2 in all seriousness I can't tell the difference between a good beard and a bad beard. But you didn't have a beard before and now you do, so presumably you grew it deliberately and know what you're doing therefore I conclude it's probably a nice beard.

You could reword my first comment as "Hey, Destin now has a beard, and I have noticed this" if you like!

If you need to set the aperture before doing this, you can often set the Av you want, then hold the DoP button while taking the lens off.  That way the Av won't close down when you remove the lens and it'll keep your setting while off the camera.
My friend showed me this trick about a year ago and its awesome. Even my cheap crappy dslr gets nice macropictures now ;D
@spacefaget Covered, yes. Dustproof, not. Let alone Live View models.
Congratulations, you took photos of frost on a window
How do you get the camera to take pictures without a lens attached?
handy tip, thanks.

@abraxsis Why look for trouble? I can and usually clean my sensor myself, but the odds of scatching the filter in front of it increase with the frequency you do clean it. I'd rather keep it to a minimum, YMMV.
sweet!
Um,  nice :)
@TheHiddenPart Or maybe learn how to clean them yourself? A sensor isn't nitroglycerin, it wont explode if you touch it.

Great way to allow dust particles on your sensor. Never take your lenses off with the camera on..
I know, I know modern DSLRs have automatic sensor cleaning, but still...
